"Moving homes. Shifting survival.
Nomadic worlds describe cultures that thrive by relocating—seasonally, annually, or across generations.<[silence:2400]>

Unlike fixed settlements, nomads adapt to land, not the other way around.<[silence:1200]>
The Mongols’ ger (yurt) collapses in minutes, carried by horses.<[silence:1200]>
Sami reindeer herders in Scandinavia follow migration routes older than written history.<[silence:1200]>
Some, like the Bedouin, navigate deserts using star patterns and camel endurance.<[silence:2400]>

Their tools are precision: the chum tent of Siberian Nenets resists -50°C winds.<[silence:1200]>
Maasai warriors memorize 1,000+ plant uses to heal, poison, or feed.<[silence:1200]>
No excess—only what fits on a sled, a camel, or a back.<[silence:2400]>

Today, satellites track the last nomadic routes.<[silence:1200]>
Climate shifts and borders shrink their paths.<[silence:1200]>
Yet their knowledge—of drought-resistant crops, invisible water sources—outlasts empires.<[silence:1200]>

Adaptation without roots.
Memory as a map.
The art of leaving no trace."
